column31: I really think there's nothing wrong with the interface
column32: Any mutants that haven't been killed at the end give extra points for the attacker. More points for the attacker for each defender fail. More points for the defender if they kill a mutant with their first try, and gradually less points for each fail.

column31: Don't let the error message disappear automatically
column33: Make it easier to understand what to do when mutants stack

column31: I would prefer if the interface did not use bootstrap.

column32: I didn't really pay attention to it

column32: Have more time for the rounds

column31: Standard IDE features (autocomplete, code hints, JavaDoc)
column32: Number of tests before a mutant gets killed divided size (in chars) of the diff
column33: Allow users to write more than one tests while they wait - would make a cool code review tool to add to something like Gerrit

column31: I think having 4 panels separates things nicely, but it sometimes can be confusing to have all the information displayed. Perhaps have selectors for which panels should be covered
column32: I think it is at the moment a bit unclear what earns points. Point earning should refresh the page.
column33: It is too hard to claim equivalence in hard mode - I'm not sure on how to improve this, but only seeing the line change is not enough to determine equivalence even for a person.

column31: The text editor sometimes doesn't work if you double click a line and try to paste in code
column32: Explanation of the scoring system - it wasn't apparent what the scoring system was (presumably one point for each surving mutant per turn?)
column33: A time limit per turn, so the game reverts back to the other player (or perhaps some way to ping the other player to take their turn)

column31: vim-like controls
column32: I'm not really sure how it's working or what's going on, so making it easier to see what's going on would help.
column33: Allow the use of loops and more advanced programming features, perhaps with a time-out of some kind. This would make it significantly better.

column31: Leave errors open for longer / have a close button
column32: Time based as well
column33: Not really :)

column31: Error messages as to why your code didn't compile or didn't pass the tests should stay up longer and not disappear. Your code you write shouldn't suddenly disappear before a round starts.
column32: Defenders should get more points for successful tests, as it is much harder.

column31: Keep the error up for longer when running defend with errors.
Just in the interface's color should be darker than now
no
column32: fix bugs
column33: fix bugs

column31: Make it more clear that the class under test is the original, working class.
column32: Longer trials, more rounds?

column33: I think a more intuitive tutorial is required, explaining exactly "what" you're testing against, and how that relates to what's on screen. It was confusing at first when I didn't realise the code on the left was the source code, and that some anonymous change had been made to line 'x'. I think this needs to be made more obvious.
Leaderboard would be nice to have to see all the code defenders who are undoubtedly worse than me.

column31: Keep compile errors on screen.  Make code window larger vertically so more of the code can be seen at once.
column32: Make both users send a mutation, then both try and defend the other's mutation simultaneously. Extra points for faster beating of test/less tries.
column33: Allow attackers to write a test that beats their mutation, if the defender can't defend within a certain number of tries/time limit, allow the attacker to submit their test and move on (not necessarily winning a point though).

column31: Add code completion, better highlight non-compiling code, make it clearer which parts of the JUnit test interface are editable
column32: I'm not sure adding the number of all active mutants to the attacker's score is fair/leads to writing good unit tests. For example, let's say I've accumulated a few mutants that changed completly different parts of the code. As a defender, I'm then inclined to write one big unit test function that covers all those changes, which might be all over the code.
column33: Why can I defend, even though there are no mutants alive? My previous tests killed the new mutant. That situation is not motivating me to write even more unit tests.

column31: Highlight/(draw attention to) what's required to be read to effectively complete the round eg line that changed
column33: VIM mode && IDE features would be nice. Non-trivial to implement in a web browser I guess...

column31: Auto-completion
column32: More points for more complicated mutations
column33: Option to run test case against original code without mutation to see if your test is at least initially right. This would make complicated classes easier to write tests for. At the moment it is hard to figure out if I have even understood the method correctly.

column31: Looks good
column32: Leaderboards would be cool.
